data.title: The Honeymoon Dilemma: A Honeymoon With Kids vs Without
data.meta_description: Honeymoon with kids vs without - the age-old questions. I've broken it down into pros and cons to help you make that decision.
data.text:
Having a honeymoon seems like a rite of passage if you’re having a wedding. The only thing is, most people are getting married later now, when they already have children in their lives. Which causes a bit of a dilemma – honeymoon with kids or without?

Both options are totally valid, but it can be difficult to decide. A honeymoon is designed to give the happy couple some quality time together. Bringing kids can definitely disrupt that, but are you comfortable with leaving your kids behind? Does the the honeymoon get swallowed up as a family holiday and leave the newlyweds out of the picture?

It’s a difficult choice to make, so I’ve created this list of pros and cons for each. Hopefully the points made will help you make up your mind about how you’d like to honeymoon – will be with the kids or without?

Honeymoon with Kids: A Family Adventure

The idea of a family honeymoon is gaining popularity, and for good reason. Including children in this special journey can deepen family bonds and create lasting memories. Here are some compelling arguments in favor of a honeymoon with kids:

Family Bonding:

Pros: Sharing the honeymoon experience with children allows for a unique bonding opportunity. Exploring new destinations together can strengthen family ties and provide a sense of unity as you navigate unfamiliar territories as a team.

Cons: On the flip side, the honeymoon is traditionally a time for the couple to strengthen their marital bond. The presence of children may dilute the focus on each other, potentially diminishing the romantic aspect of the trip.

Educational Value:

Pros: Traveling with kids offers an excellent chance for them to learn about different cultures, history, and geography. Experiencing new cuisines, traditions, and languages firsthand can be a rich educational experience.

Cons: However, not all destinations may be suitable for children, and balancing educational opportunities with age-appropriate activities can be challenging. Parents might find themselves torn between cultural exploration and providing entertainment for their children.

Inclusive Memories:

Pros: Including children in the honeymoon ensures that they become part of the family narrative from the very beginning. Shared memories of the trip can become a cherished part of family lore and traditions.

Cons: The danger lies in the potential for children to feel burdened by the expectations of creating perfect family memories. Balancing individual and family experiences may prove challenging, as the desires of adults and children may not always align.

Teaching Life Skills:

Pros: Traveling teaches children important life skills such as adaptability, resourcefulness, and an appreciation for diversity. Experiencing the world beyond their immediate surroundings can broaden their perspectives.

Cons: The challenges of travel, such as navigating airports, adjusting to time zone changes, and managing unexpected disruptions, can be overwhelming for children. Striking a balance between exposing them to new experiences and ensuring their comfort is crucial.

Honeymoon Without Kids: Rekindling Romance

Opting for a honeymoon without children can provide couples with a romantic escape, fostering intimacy and allowing for undivided attention. Below are some advantages and disadvantages of this more traditional approach:

Uninterrupted Romance:

Pros: A child-free honeymoon allows couples to focus solely on each other, rekindling the romantic spark that may have been overshadowed by the responsibilities of parenthood. It provides an opportunity to reconnect emotionally and physically.

Cons: The absence of children may lead to feelings of guilt or a sense of missing out on creating family memories. You’ll probably miss them and the whole experience could fall flat if you feel an essential part of your family unit has been missing the whole time.

Freedom and Spontaneity:

Pros: Without the constraints of children’s schedules and preferences, couples can enjoy a more spontaneous and flexible itinerary. Exploring new destinations at their own pace and leisure becomes a liberating experience.

Cons: The downside is the potential loneliness or sense of incompleteness that may arise when parents are accustomed to the constant presence of their children. It’s important to strike a balance and acknowledge the transitional nature of the honeymoon period.

Recharging Parental Batteries:

Pros: A kid-free honeymoon offers parents the chance to rest and recharge, both physically and emotionally. The break from the demands of parenting can result in a more patient, energized, and present approach to family life upon their return.

Cons: The guilt associated with leaving children behind can cast a shadow on the trip, and the fear of missing significant moments in their lives may be a constant undercurrent throughout the honeymoon.

Luxury and Indulgence:

Pros: Child-free honeymoons often allow for indulgence in luxury accommodations, fine dining, and activities that may not be suitable for children. Couples can create a once-in-a-lifetime experience tailored exclusively to their desires.

Cons: The potential for judgment from others for leaving children behind can be a source of stress. Society’s expectations and perceived notions of responsible parenting may weigh heavily on the couple’s decision.

Final Thoughts on the Honeymoon Dilemma

In the end, the decision to have a honeymoon with or without children boils down to personal preferences, priorities, and circumstances.

It can be hard to get a sitter that you’re comfortable with leaving the kids with while you’re out of the country (or the town). Most grandparents are busy these days, and if your own set of parents are still quite young, chances are that they’re still working. So even if you get someone willing to sit for you, it might not really work out.
